metadata.case_name: Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India

facts.text: Central Government requisitioned certain properties belonging to Hanskumar Kishanchand on February 19, 1941, under s.75A of the Rules framed under the Defence of India Act, 1939.
No agreement on compensation amount, referred to Mr. Jafry, Additional District Judge, Khandwa, under s.19(1)(b) of the Defence of India Act.
Mr. Jafry pronounced award on March 31, 1943, awarding Rs. 13,000 as annual rent for occupation of the premises.
Appeal to High Court of Nagpur under s.19(1)(f) of the Act, heard by Grille C.J. and Padhye J.
High Court judgment dated December 31, 1947, enhanced annual rent by Rs. 3,250 (to Rs. 16,250) and allowed compensation for dislocation of High School run on the property.
Appellant (Hanskumar) applied for leave to appeal to Federal Court under ss.109 and 110 CPC regarding amounts disallowed; Government applied regarding enhancement.
Leave granted and certificate issued on August 25, 1949, that appeals fulfilled requirements of ss.109 and 110 CPC.
Preliminary objection by Solicitor-General to maintainability of Civil Appeal No. 224/54, arguing High Court judgment is an award, not judgment/decree/order under ss.109/110 CPC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the judgment of the High Court passed in appeal under s.19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act, 1939, is a judgment, decree or order within ss.109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure, making the appeals to the Supreme Court competent.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings under s.19(1)(b) are arbitration, but once matter comes before High Court by appeal under s.19(1)(f), it becomes a civil proceeding under ordinary jurisdiction of the Court, open to appeal under ss.109 and 110 CPC; alternatively, competent under Cl.29 of Letters Patent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss.109 and 110 CPC; Cl.29 Letters Patent

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if no appeal under ss.109/110 CPC or Letters Patent, Supreme Court can grant leave under Federal Court (Enlargement of Jurisdiction) Act, 1948, s.3(a)(ii), devolved via Art.135.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Federal Court (Enlargement of Jurisdiction) Act, 1948, s.3(a)(ii); Art.135 Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Reference under s.19(1)(b) and appeal under s.19(1)(f) are arbitration proceedings; High Court decision is an award, not judgment/decree/order under ss.109/110 CPC.

court_reasoning.text: Arbitration proceedings, whether by agreement or statute, result in award not appealable under ordinary law unless statute provides; distinction between Court as Court vs. persona designata.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reference under s.19(1)(b) to arbitrator (qualified for High Court Judge); appeal under s.19(1)(f) continues arbitration, High Court acts as designated authority, not as Court.

court_reasoning.text: s.19(1)(f) refers to arbitrator's decision as 'award'; appeal is continuation of arbitration proceedings, retains character as such.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court decision is not judgment/decree/order under ss.109/110 CPC or Letters Patent.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras that s.19(1)(g) covers entire proceedings including High Court appeal as arbitration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No power to grant special leave as decision is award, not judgment.

holdings.text: Decision of High Court in appeal under s.19(1)(f) of Defence of India Act is an award in arbitration proceedings, not a judgment, decree or order appealable under ss.109/110 CPC or Letters Patent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rangoon Botatoung Company v. The Collector, Rangoon
precedents_cited.relevance: Decision in Land Acquisition reference to Court is award, not appealable.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dossabhai Bezonji
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court appeal under Land Acquisition Act s.54 not judgment under Letters Patent.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Special Officer, Salsette Building Sites v. Dassabhai Basanji Motiwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Privy Council accepted Bombay High Court view on non-appealability.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manavikraman Tirumalpad v. The Collector of the Nilgris
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court appeal under Land Acquisition not judgment under Letters Patent Cl.15.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: No appeal from High Court under Calcutta Improvement Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General
precedents_cited.relevance: Reference to established Court imports ordinary procedure and appeal rights; unlike statutory arbitration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India v. Chelikani Rama Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between Court as Court vs. arbitrator; Forest Act proceedings as litigation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal under s.19(1)(f) Defence of India Act is arbitration proceeding.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs requisition, compensation determination by arbitrator, appeal to High Court as arbitration.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Appealability of judgments/decrees/orders; certificate issued but held inapplicable.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Arbitrator to have regard to its provisions; analogies to non-appealability of awards.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs arbitration awards; limited appeals; applies to statutory arbitrations.

statutes_cited.name: Federal Court (Enlargement of Jurisdiction) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave power limited to judgments.

outcome.summary: Both appeals dismissed as incompetent since High Court decision under s.19(1)(f) Defence of India Act is an award in arbitration proceedings, not appealable under ss.109/110 CPC or Letters Patent.

key_quotes.text: Their Lordships cannot accept the argument or suggestion that when once the claimant is admitted to the High Court he has all the rights of an ordinary suitor, including the right to carry an award made in an arbitration as to the value of land taken for public purposes up to this Board as if it were a decree of the High Court made in the course of its ordinary jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Rangoon Botatoung, key to non-appealability principle.

key_quotes.text: When a question is stated to be referred to an established Court without more, it, in my opinion, imports that the ordinary incidents of the procedure of that Court are to attach, and also that any general right of appeal from its decision likewise attaches.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From National Telephone, distinguishes Court as Court vs. arbitrator.

key_quotes.text: We must therefore hold that the decision of the High Court in the appeal under that provision is not a judgment, decree or order either within ss.109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure or cl.29 of the Letters Patent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on incompetence of appeals.
